On 14/01/2008, csabcsi.szucs <csaba.szucs@...> wrote:
>  1)
>  Do I break the basic JUnit rule of class isolation if I do NOT isolate
>  a class from its collaborators that have already been tested?
>
>  So do I still need mock/stub/fake objects for tested dependant classes
>  in any case?

No.  It's a matter of balance.

I usually use mock objects where the real object has a plug-in point
at which it talks through an interface to another object.  The test
needs to express how the object calls out through the interface, not
how the object and one specific implementation  work.

I also often introduce mock objects if the collaborator is
complicated, so the test of the object and its collaborator would have
to cover a large number of combinations.

I especially don't mock value objects.  I have tests for the value
types, and then just use the value types in tests.

>  2)
>  Is there any strategy/method in what order you can test classes for an
>  existing project?

Do you mean the order in which you write the tests, or in which the
tests are run?

I write a test just before I write the code to make it pass.

I don't assume that they run in any particular order, and so ensure
they are completely independent from one another.

--Nat
